item.description:
The 17th International Contemporary Artists' Book Fair forms the core of PAGES, an ongoing project of interrelated events establishing critical engagement with the medium of the artists' book, encouraging production and awareness and establishing an arena for display and for exchange between audience and maker.
PAGES is pleased to announce its new partnership with The Tetley. With the past use and present structure of the building in mind, a series of exhibitions and installations are also in development alongside the fair, on the themes of archive and office, stationary and document, marginalia and cataloguing, and accumulations and inventories. The event will also incorporate a comprehensive series of discussions, lectures and forums during the Saturday and Sunday, and related exhibitions across the city.
Highlights will include Image>Archive<Memory, an exhibition by British-Armenian artist Karen Babayan, with performances by London-based dancer Shakeh Major Tchilingirian, and a talk by Research Professor in Curation and Art History, Lynda Morris, at the Artists' Book Fair Dinner. See 'Events' pages for booking details. Stallholders at the Fair will include artists and publishers from around the UK, artists participating in A New Reality at The Tetley, Leeds-based collective Spur and Leeds' finest independent bookstore, Village.
PAGES 2014 Artists' Book Fair Participants
ABC artists book club / Alice Fox / Ambeck Design /AMBruno / Amelia Crouch /AP Books / Are we nearly there yet? / Art & Design, University of Leeds / Artistsbooksonline/ Batley School of Art, Fine Art for Design / Becoming Press / Cafe Royal Books / Camberwell College of Arts, MA Book Arts / Carla Moss / Charlotte Victoria Furness / Chris Taylor / David Barton /Ensixteen Editions / Essence Press / Fine Art, University of Leeds / Filippa Dobson / Ghosts Publications / Incline Press / Interdisciplinary Art and Design, Leeds College Art / Jane Cradock-Watson / Jane Hyslop / Joan Ainley / Joanna Wilkinson /John Barrett / John McDowall / Karoline Rerrie / Kim Bevan / Kristine Steele / Leeds City College / Leeds College of Art: BA Visual Communication / Louise Atkinson / Mandy Brannan / Mr Smith / New Arcadian Press / Old Bear Press / PagePaperStitch / PAPER / Pat Hodson / Pink Parrot Press / PJB Editions / F. J. Ratchford Ltd. / Roncadora Press / Sandra Whyles / Shaeron Caton-Rose / Sheffield Hallam University MA Fine Art / and Guerrilla Writers / Stef Mitchell / Surrealist Editions / The Caseroom Press / Theresa Easton / Thomas Tomasska / University of Central Lancashire: Drawing and Image Making / Victoria Lucas / Weproductions / whnicPRESS / Wild Pansy Press / A New Reality artists and collaborators (Joe Gilmore, Aidan Moesby and Nous Vous with Spur, Village Book Store and Catalogue)
Join Gavin Extence, author of The Universe Versus Alex Woods, to hear him talk about the book and his writing.

item.event_title: Lore Of The North Book Launch
item.description:
''The moor was still, poised at this hour as if this extraordinary event had dispelled time...'
The launch sees Lord Whitney's Lore of the North project presented in an exciting publication and exhibition, based on Yorkshire Folklore.
Food, drink, and an Introductory talk by Stephen Sayers (6pm).
In association with Food&_ and The Social, with drinks to follow at newly opened The Social.
If you've missed the project, catch up here - http://loreofthenorth.tumblr.com/ www.lordwhitney.co.uk
Supported by Grants for the Arts and Leeds Inspired

INSCRIBE Masterclass series.
Three monthly sessions. The series offers a compact survey of Jacob Ross' immensely popular and highly regarded technical creative approach to crafting fiction. His very successful course has been running for more than fifteen years. Many beginning writers developed and fine-tuned their writing skills in his course, to the point where their work has been shortlisted in major competitions, or won prizes.
Narrative Drive is for writers who want to maximise the quality and impact of their work. At the end of the series you will have a better awareness of your own strengths and weakness as a writer and the steps you need to take to address them. We will examine the building blocks of stories and how they work together to produce strong memorable narratives.
The series will expose you to the very best examples of modern fiction from which you can learn and refine your skills. Your knowledge of contemporary themes and styles will be enhanced. This course is for advanced writers already working on their novel-in-progress or their collection of short stories. You will be required to submit work in advance of the course.

Presented by Headingley Litfest.
Local poet and Words on Tap host Matthew Hedley Stoppard will lead a workshop focusing on some essentials to perpetuate your poetry. The afternoon will incorporate the importance of 'voice' using vinyl recordings of poets, technique and figures of speech, with close attention to zeugma, and poetry games. Any profits from this event will be donated to Help for Heroes. Contact: wordsontap@email.com
Following on from the Words on Tap workshops held at All Hallows Church in Hyde Park in spring last year, this session will encourage the beginnings of poems rather than force finished articles by the end of the three hours. The workshop leader also aims to prompt discussion amongst attendees and examine the reader's perceptions of poetry.
Matthew Hedley Stoppard was born in Derbyshire and lives in East Leeds with his wife and children. His debut collection A Family Behind Glass was included in The Guardian's Readers' Books of the Year 2013 and his poems and stories appear in various magazines and anthologies, both in print and online, and green vinyl disc. He is also a competition winner and founder/organiser/host of monthly not-for-profit literary event Words on Tap.

The Workers' Educational Association presents a collection of poetry, short stories and plays based around the LitFest theme of surviving.
The event will feature the work of two of the WEA's weekly classes with Alison Taft (creative writing and dramatic writing) both of which meet in Heart, Headingley, together with the work of writers from the Osmondthorpe Resource Centre.
Expect to be moved, surprised and entertained as the writers share their experiences and interpretations of this year's theme.

Partnership Event with Leeds Combined Arts
Helen Burke is a writer, performance poet, visual artist and fabric designer. Her work has been set to music both here and in America. She has read in London, Paris, New York, and Rhode Island in the U.S. with the Poet Laureate.
She regularly hosts a radio show for East Leeds FM Radio.
Her work has been translated into French and Romanian - and shortly into Dutch, and Italian. She is to read later this year in Rome, where she will judge the Keats/Shelley Prize for young people.
She holds an M.A. in Literature and likes to make her poetry accessible, fun, thought provoking and entertaining for the listener.

Carriageworks Theatre is working closely with Proper Job Theatre Company in the ongoing development of their fresh take on the well-known tale of the original monster movie Nosferatu.
We are hosting a rehearsed reading of the script, written by Yorkshire based poet Ian McMillan. There is an original score performed live with singing.
"On the blood dark sea the ship is barely moving There's a sail as torn as a shattered shirt Something is aboard the ship..."
Nosferatu tells the dark and mysterious tale of the sailors in Bram Stokers novel Dracula, as they journey from Varna to Whitby with an unknown cargo.
This is a fantastic chance to be one of the first to see a new groundbreaking piece of theatre, feeding into the shaping and impression of the play, which will embark on a national tour in 2015. We need your feedback so please join us for an evening of blood, danger and art!
Proper Job Theatre Company is based in the North of England creating and touring new work as well as large-scale theatre events. Proper Job are passionate about continuously developing projects that excite us, fire our curiosity and expand our imagination.

With John Wedgewood Clarke.
We are very pleased to welcome Gillian Clarke, the National Poet of Wales, to Headingley LitFest. Gillian, to our great delight, has agreed to headline our poetry event on 20 March in the place of Jo Shapcott who is now unable to take part this year.
Gillian is a central figure in contemporary Welsh poetry and her poems have achieved widespread critical and popular acclaim. The Poetry Archive celebrates her achievements noting that: Listening to a Gillian Clarke poem is an intensely sensual experience; her use of language "concrete as it is musical" (Times Literary Supplement) and the patterning of rhyme and alliteration combine to give the impression of a poem as an almost physical object...
Gillian Clarke was born in Cardiff and lives in Ceredigion. National Poet for Wales since 2008, she is President of TÃÂ ÃÂ· Newydd, the Welsh Writers Centre which she co-founded in 1990. Her work is widely studied for GCSE and A Level. She has published thirteen books for adults, and several for children as writer, translator or editor. Her first prose collection, At the Source, ap-peared in 2008. Her recent collection of poems, Ice, was short-listed for the TS Eliot Award 2012. In December 2010 she was awarded the Queen's Gold Medal for Poetry, and in 2012 the Wilfred Owen Award.
John Wedgwood Clarke was born in St.Ives, Cornwall and now lives in Scarborough. He founded and ran the Beverley Literature Festival and Bridlington Poetry Festival until 2012.

Stories of a boy growing up in Warsaw. New York, 1978.
The cab driver is waiting to take him to the airport. The evening before he travels to Stockholm to collect the Nobel Prize for Literature, Isaac Bashevis Singer - a passionate, brilliant storyteller - recalls a fascinating childhood full of mystery, torment and adventure.
A Day of Pleasure is about more than a young boy growing up in a strange and exotic world; it is about growing up itself. Singer brings to life the vivid characters of pre-war Warsaw, his own character and the human conditions that affect us all.

You will find Otley Word Feast Quote Cards all around Otley town in the week leading up to the Feast Celebration Weekend, 28-30th March 2014. Identify the poems and novels, poets and authors, then check your answers in the window of Otley CORE on Saturday 29th March.
Collect a complete set of 20 Quote Cards to be in the running for a prize.

Ridiculous Witches... "Not Good. Not Wicked. Just Ridiculous"
Local children's Author Sarah Shafi will be reading her latest hilarious story "The Odd Legged Car Crashing Witch of Leeds" from her Ridiculous Witch series aimed at 6-10 year old boys and girls.
There's a motoring maniac loose on the streets of Leeds. Always disappearing from the scene of a crime, this menace has become Inspector Pileup's biggest nightmare. But this menace has a BIG secret and seventeen year-old Tommy Carburretor is determined to find out.
But will he?
Read out loud and laugh out loud. ...Ridiculous Witches are a fun read for all the family.

For many people, the First World War is indelibly associated with the poetry of Wilfred Owen, Siegfried Sassoon and Rupert Brooke. Yet the poetic output of British, Dominion and American troops was far more extensive than the well known works of the best known poets.
This event will explore some of the lesserknown poems and poetry, including works by A.E. Mackintosh and Alan Seegar, as well as poetry published in hospital fundraising magazines such as The Gazette of the Third London General Hospital.
Dr Jessica Meyer will discuss how such poetry has informed her own work as a historian of the First World War and the continuing cultural impact of war poetry on British understandings of the war and its centenary commemoration.

Jean Davison will read from her memoir The Dark Threads and talk about her experiences as a patient a High Royds psychiatric hospital in the 1970s.
Electric Shock Treatment and drugs reduced her to a zombie-like state for five years, before she managed to turn her life around. The talk will also include her experiences of writing the book and getting published.

Welcome to the March Fictions event, where we invite you to reflect on the theme of 'home'. Whether 'home' means a back-to-back terraced house, a tent pitched in a bit of wasteland, or an abandoned rocket on the surface of the moon, Fictions invites you to riff off real or imaginary dwellings past or present.
Our invited speakers at this event are:
ZODWA NYONI Zimbabwean-born poet and playwright, who has held residencies at BBC Radio Leeds and at the Ilkley Literature Festival, Zodwa was recently named one of Leeds' 20 best writers under 40, and is certainly one of Fictions' favourite poets. Don't miss this opportunity to see her in action!
NASSER HUSSAIN Nasser is looking forward to the forthcoming publication of his first collection of spoken word poems, entitled 'boldface' - available this summer from Burning Eye Press. In the meantime he teaches literature and creative writing at Leeds Metropolitan University, and is currently at work on something completely different.
Music at this event will come from DAVID BROAD.
OPEN MIC. There will be a writers' open mic, at which contributions of flash fiction, short fiction, true stories, and excerpts of larger work will all be welcome. You MUST keep your contributions under 6 minutes because if you go over, YOU WILL BE STOPPED. Even in the middle of a sentence if it comes to it. Please practise reading your work out to check that it comes in under 6 minutes - we're taking the very un-Fictions-like step of being firm about this.

Poetry by Heart is one of Headingley's regular cultural events, which takes place on the last Wednesday of each month in the Cafe of the Heart Centre.
Six poets each have fifteen minutes to showcase their work. Admission is free and the poets receive no fees or expenses, but they do have the opportunity to sell books.
This special session for Headingley LitFest features six popular Yorkshire poets: Jonathan Eyre, Geoff Hattersley, Mark Hinchcliffe, Sally Goldsmith, Cora Greenhill and River Wolton.

This enjoyable feast of words showcases local talent and established writers with an exciting programme for all the community with many free events, at the Courthouse and other town venues. Highlights include creative writing workshops, open mic and slam competitions, author events, speakers, children and family activities.
For the latest programme news, see www.otleywordfeast.org.uk and check www.otleycourthouse.org.uk for ticket and booking information.

Come and enjoy the opening event of the second Otley Word Feast with:
Bards in Their Eyes Brenda Cromwell Joanne Brown John Hepworth
- and a veggie curry feast!

Can you talk and eat breakfast at the same time?
Come and discuss how you get from the blank page to the finished manuscript or poem. Local writers will be starting off the discussion. Let us know if you would like to be one of them.

item.event_title: Write A Novel In A Weekend?
item.description:
with James Wheatley.
This workshop will give you the opportunity to think about how to build a story you can write, dealing with various aspects of planning, structuring and plotting novels. If you've got an idea for a novel, but haven't quite developed the story, this might be the workshop for you.

with Glynis Charlton
Where do you get your ideas from? has to be one of the most common questions put to authors. There's no straight answer. At this friendly workshop, suitable for beginners and developers, you'll discover ways into your writing - and see that ideas are all around us.

Delve into a treasure chest of poetic prompts to find inspiration and poems which might surprise you. Consider how not only imagery, but also sounds, tastes, scents and textures can enrich your work. Expect a good-natured, supportive and friendly session, hosted by experienced creative writing facilitator and poet, Suzanne McArdle.

with Pat Belford
Ever wanted to write stories for children? Whether adventures, magical tales of fantasy or bedtime stories, Pat will get you started with lots of ideas for plots and characters. You will be writing short, fun exercises to give you the basis for at least one children's story.
Visit Otley Library for an hour of interactive stories and parachute games with Otley Children's Centre and Leeds Libraries.

Stories of the Co-op in Yorkshire with Michael McGowan
Michael has wide experience of the co-operative movement in Yorkshire and the developing world especially Africa. He is the former MEP for Leeds and President of the Third World Development Committee of the European Parliament. He has worked as a television and radio producer with the BBC and is a member of the National Union of Journalists.

item.event_title: Come to Otley Library - Horrid Henry's Foul Feast
item.description: Help us to celebrate Otley Word Feast by creating your own recipe for the most Foul Feast. Write a list of ingredients and draw a picture of your dish. There are four Horrid Henry books signed by the author, Francesca Simon, for the 'worst' recipes!
Come to the CORE in Otley to collect your Trail Form and hunt for the Roger Hargreaves Mr Men books displayed in Otley town shop windows. The first six correct entries win a Mr Men book.

The winners of the Otley Word Feast creative writing competition, for under 18's, on the theme of 'Market' will be announced in Otley Library by the Town Mayor.
Please note, no photography is allowed in Otley Library.

item.event_title: The Return Of The Despicable Liars
item.description:
Meet Jeanette Martin of Otley Walking Festival at the Fleece Pub for a captivating afternoon of story-telling in the Snug.
This is the first time some of the great Otley deceptions will be aired to the public. Don't miss this thought-provoking, discussion inducing and richly amusing event.

with Noel Whittall.
A surprise star of the first Otley Word Feast was 'H', Noel's ancient Triumph motorcycle which had featured in his book 'A Stupid Thing to Do', the tale of a meandering lone ride from John o' Groats to Land's End and back again. Now Noel and H have been at it again, this time down through France and over the highest passes in the Alps to Monaco where they did a slow lap of the Grand Prix circuit.

Introducing the wonderful world of fillers with Linda Lewis
Fillers are small pieces of writing - readers' letters, true stories and so on in magazines. The rewards can be very good indeed. There are all kinds of opportunities available. This workshop will look at a cross section of these, including some of the more light-hearted ones.

with Vickie Orton
Join local storyteller Vickie Orton for a whirlwind of stories for all the family to enjoy about wings, feathers and the unexpected. Learn how a small girl saved her father's life with a kite and how a sculptor was saved by his own statue.
For children and their adults together.

item.event_title: A Guide To The Townscape of Otley
item.description: For overy 40 years Paul Wood has translated the historic Otley runes in words and picture. The author will outline research techniques, narrative themes and graphic reconstructions.

item.event_title: Otley Word Feast Youth Poetry Slam
item.description:
With only three minutes to enthral the audience and judges, young poets take their words from the page to the stage at this year's poetry slam. The youth poetry competition will give writers in Otley a platform to showcase their original work.
Join us at the Otley Courthouse and support your local writers! Hosted by Zodwa Nyoni

item.event_title: A Terribly Sedate And Right Proper Poetry Reading
item.description:
with Char March
If you've never thought poetry is your bag, and the thought of going to a poetry performance fills you with horror... think again! Char March is a multi-award-winning poet and playwright, and her poetry performances are a rip-roaring mix of stand-up and emotional roller-coaster - she'll have you crying with laughter and roaring with tears. (And she's the judge for our Open Mic - straight after her performance - so come along and get some tips!) Char has supported Otley WordFeast from the start, and says: "I've performed at hundreds of LitFests around Britain and abroad, and Otley WordFeast is definitely the friendliest, the most supportive, and the most fun one - by miles! Go Otley!"

How do writers heighten and sustain pace and tension? What do you need to plan the perfect murder? And can you get away with it?
Amazon award winning author of Shallow be thy Grave, Alison Taft, brings us a Crime Writing Workshop.

with Martyn Bedford
For ages 12-16. From Harry Potter to Katniss Everdeen, characters are the key ingredient of a successful story. In this workshop, aimed at beginners and developing writers, novelist Martyn Bedford will use short-burst and extended writing exercises to help sharpen your skills in creating interesting fictional characters.

with James Nash
James will be reading from his latest collection 'Some Things Matter' and talking about how and why he writes. Humorous, touching and occasionally slightly risque - for scone-scoffers and poetry lovers everywhere.

Host: Brendan McPartlan Judge: Char March
You have three minutes to perform and convince us all that you deserve a cash prize! Get your name down early as there is limited space.
Email: mic@otleywordfeast.org.uk to reserve a slot.

In conjunction with The Courthouse Presented by Blaize with Hommel Arts Through song, poetry and narration, Standing In Line tells the story of the Great War, but specifically about Albert Scrimshaw, Lester Simpson's great uncle, who died at Passendale. Originally commissioned by 'Peace Concerts Passendale', it was premiered in Passendale Church, Belgium in 2003.
The performance is centred around Lester's songs though includes songs from the time. The narration includes poems of Wilfred Owen, Siegfried Sassoon and Rudyard Kipling and is accompanied by a series of projected images. Written by Lester Simpson & Piet Chielans.

Laydeez do Comics is the UK's first women's led comics forum, that focuses on autobiographical comics and dramas of the everyday. It was started by illustrator Nicola Streeten & artist Sarah Lightman in London in 2009. In 2011 illustrator Lou Crosby set up Laydeez do Comics in Leeds which now runs bi-monthly.
Laydeez do Comics, Leeds presents it's first themed night ...
... This will form part of the Yorkshire Festival 2014, the first ever Arts & Cultural Festival in the lead up the Tour de France. The Grand Depart 2014 starts in Yorkshire on the 5th July and the Yorkshire Festival runs for the 100 days up to the 6th July.
COMICS & THE SENSES 31st March 2014 Starts 6.30pm prompt Ends 9.15 pm (approx) £1.50 All welcome (mixed event)
Speakers
Ian Hague - academic and director of Comics Forum. Author of Comics and the Senses: A Multisensory Approach to Comics and Graphic Novels. Talking about his research into the ways comics stimulate all 5 senses and are challenge the idea that comics are purely visual in nature. www.ianhague.com www.abpositivecomic.com
Louise Crosby & Clare Shaw - Illustrator and poet. Poetry performance and a talk about their collaboration, Seeing Poetry: Poetry in Words and Comics. www.facebook.com/SeeingPoetry www.clareshaw.co.uk www.lindenartstudio.org/artists/louise-crosby/
Ravi Thornton & Dr Matt Green - Ravi is a award winning cross-media writer whose work includes the debut graphic novel The Tale Of Brin & Bent And Minno Marylebone. Ravi will be speaking about her present project HOAX My Lonely Heart a musical stage performance, and HOAX Psychosis Blues a graphic novel. ravithornton.com Matt is an academic from University of Nottingham who edited Alan Moore and the Gothic Tradition. He is working with Ravi on several projects. He will be speaking about this & the gothic tradition in comics. http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/english/people/matt.green

item.event_title: Him With His Foot In His Mouth
item.description:
Harry Shawmut is funny, charming, self-doubting and neurotic... A man who often says things he shouldn't. He once made a wise crack to a lady in passing and now, 35 years later and racked with guilt, he has tracked her down to your neighbourhood to apologise.
But saying sorry isn't always that simple... Witness the most elaborate apology in history as Harry introduces us to the family, friends, enemies, mystics and con men that make up his uniquely funny and moving life story. Prepare for a host of throw away lines and dry humour as Harry prepares to make amends.
This heart-warming new production marks the first ever UK stage adaptation of a work by the great American writer Saul Bellow, three times winner of the National Book Award and winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature.

Shaking hands with Satan
'Mantel... instinctively grabs for the reachably real' The New Yorker
From rumours that Anne Boleyn sold her soul for her crown to the Faustian pacts of the technology age, Hilary Mantel investigates the history of the human relationship with the devil.
The double Man Booker Prize-winning author (Wolf Hall, Bring up the Bodies) says that whilst growing up, the devil was a vital presence in her own life and so it was only natural that he should feature in her novels. In this specially commissioned talk, she traces the footsteps of the devil in her life, her fiction and in today's world.
This talk has been rescheduled from Autumn 2012 and includes live music from violinist David le Page.
Commissioned by Opera North Projects

Join us for an evening with award winning author John Connolly as he launches his new book.
The Wolf in Winter is the latest crime thriller in the series featuring Charlie Parker; 'the fictional character that every man wants to be - and every woman wants to be saved by' .
The event will include John talking about his books and writing, followed by a question and answer session and book signing.
